column1: The person may receive: - Activated charcoal - Airway support, including oxygen, breathing tube through the mouth (intubation), and breathing machine (ventilator) - Blood and urine tests - Chest x-ray - CT (computerized tomography, or advanced imaging) scan - EKG (electrocardiogram, or heart tracing) - Fluids through a vein (intravenous or IV) - Medicines to treat symptoms, including antidotes to reverse the effect of the poison (fomepizole or ethanol) - Tube through the nose to remove remaining poison, if the person is seen within 60 minutes after swallowing it Because rapid removal of methanol is a key to treatment success and survival, the person will likely need dialysis (kidney machine).
